Personally I don't have this problem but several users report a problem with crashes due to the simple creation of a new MenuItem in a popup-menu on a Canvas.
The problem I have with this is that it's hard, actually impossible to trace the origin of this. There is no indication as to what might be the problem.  Also, it can work fine for days on end and then fail without any aparant difference in the environment, java runtime.
The popup-menu is always the same, not dynamically generated or anything. 

And, isn't open source wonderfull, the source code: http://www.javaforge.com/sccShowFileRevision/SpoonGraph.java?proj_id=318&tag=659&date=2006-04-15+22%3A29&filename=trunk%2Fsrc%2Fbe%2Fibridge%2Fkettle%2Fspoon%2FSpoonGraph.java

User report & stack trace follows.  I'll try to get an exact position in the SpoonGraph source code to see on which line it exactly fails.  However, the popup menu is fairly simple in nature and like I said always constructed in the same fashion.

Looking at the code (quickly), I think you are leaking.  You create a new menu every time.  When is the old menu disposed?  Since the parent of a menu is the shell, it will only get automatically disposed when the shell is closed.  Over time, Windows runs out of handles and can't create any more menu item.
